NATS
National Airspace Trajectory-Prediction System
Input & Output

Here we want to give clear discussion about the input and output of NATS system.

  • Input:
    Aircraft profile data and/or flight plan TRX file.
    The profile data is required. It includes the basic aircraft identification, aircraft type and other related information. NATS relies on these data to decide the aircraft performance capability during simulation.
    The flight plan TRX file is also important in that it tells NATS your detail plan from the starting point to the destination airport. NATS uses it as guideline to predict aircraft state in every time step.
    However, flight plan TRX file is not required if you try to send external aircraft state to NATS. In this special case, NATS will not ask for flight plan data.
  • Output:
    File of aircraft trajectory result.
    Currently NATS can output it in the following formats:
    • CSV
    • KML
    • XML

Input

There are two types of aircraft simulation in NATS:
  • Normal aircraft simulation: Simulate using input from TRX file.
  • External aircraft simulation: External aircraft data is sent to NATS Server. NATS client program sends state data of external aircrafts as input to NATS Server.

Input data of normal aircraft

The following statement loads the normal aircraft TRX file as input of NATS.
aircraftInterface.load_aircraft("share/tg/trx/TRX_DEMO_SFO_PHX_GateToGate.trx", "share/tg/trx/TRX_DEMO_SFO_PHX_mfl.trx")
This code statement load_aircraft() takes 2 arguments: TRX file and MFL file.
TRX file contains the aircraft profile data as well as their flight plans. One TRX file may store records of multiple aircraft. MFL file contains the maximum flight level data and also may have multiple aircraft data in single file.
Notice: The path of the TRX and MFL files is, by default, under NATS_Server/share/tg/trx directory. The TRX and MFL files must be placed on NATS Server, not NATS Client.

Input data of external aircraft

Sending data of external aircraft from NATS Client to Server consists of two steps:
  • Create external aircraft profile data
    simulationInterface.externalAircraft_create_trajectory_profile(String ac_id, String ac_type, String origin_airport, String destination_airport, float cruise_altitude_ft, float cruise_tas_knots, double latitude_deg, double longitude_deg, double altitude_ft, double rocd_fps, double tas_knots, double course_deg, String flight_phase)
    This function creates aircraft profile data on NATS Server. This only needs to be done once.
  • Send external aircraft state data
    simulationInterface.externalAircraft_inject_trajectory_state_data(String ac_id, double latitude_deg, double longitude_deg, double altitude_ft, double rocd_fps, double tas_knots, double course_deg, String flight_phase, long timestamp_utc_millisec)
    This function sends/injects aircraft state data to NATS Server. We usually call this function in every time step to send the current state.

Output

Output of NATS simulation is done by writing the result of trajectory data to a file.
simulationInterface.write_trajectories("Output_trajectory.csv")
This function tells NATS Server to write trajectory result to NATS_Server/Output_trajectory.csv. This file is saved on NATS Server, not on client-side.

To download the latest trajectory file, we can execute
simulationInterface.requestDownloadTrajectoryFile("Client_Downloaded.csv")

On the client-side, we will see the Client_Downloaded.csv saved under NATS_Client directory.
However, due to busy file transfer requests or huge file size, the file transfer may not start immediately.
If the trajectory file is deleted on NATS Server, this function will not save anything to client-side.
